fields.name: bind
fields.desc: Listening address and port for the gRPC server.

fields.name: ssl_options
fields.desc: SSL configuration for the gRPC server.

desc: Settings for the exproto gRPC server.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: cacerts
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.1.4.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.name: reuse_sessions
fields.desc:
Enable TLS session reuse.</br>
Has no effect when TLS version is configured (or negotiated) to 1.3

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.</br>
Has no effect when TLS version is configured (or negotiated) to 1.3

fields.name: log_level
fields.desc: Log level for SSL communication. Default is 'notice'. Set to 'debug' to inspect TLS handshake messages.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: dhfile
fields.desc:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.

fields.name: fail_if_no_peer_cert
fields.desc:
Used together with {verify, verify_peer} by an TLS/DTLS server.
If set to true, the server fails if the client does not have a
certificate to send, that is, sends an empty certificate.
If set to false, it fails only if the client sends an invalid
certificate (an empty certificate is considered valid).

fields.name: honor_cipher_order
fields.desc:
An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based
 on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,
 hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security
 ordering of the server administrator.

fields.name: client_renegotiation
fields.desc:
In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,
the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.
This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.
The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,
but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.
The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in
long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on
the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.</br>
Has no effect when TLS version is configured (or negotiated) to 1.3

fields.name: handshake_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete

fields.name: key
fields.desc: License string

fields.name: connection_low_watermark
fields.desc: Low watermark limit below which license connection quota usage alarms are deactivated

fields.name: connection_high_watermark
fields.desc: High watermark limit above which license connection quota usage alarms are activated

fields.name: xml_dir
fields.desc: The Directory for LwM2M Resource definition.

fields.name: lifetime_min
fields.desc: Minimum value of lifetime allowed to be set by the LwM2M client.

fields.name: lifetime_max
fields.desc: Maximum value of lifetime allowed to be set by the LwM2M client.

fields.name: qmode_time_window
fields.desc:
The value of the time window during which the network link is considered valid by the LwM2M Gateway in QMode mode.
For example, after receiving an update message from a client, any messages within this time window are sent directly to the LwM2M client, and all messages beyond this time window are temporarily stored in memory.

fields.name: auto_observe
fields.desc: Automatically observe the object list of REGISTER packet.

fields.name: update_msg_publish_condition
fields.desc:
Policy for publishing UPDATE event message.
- always: send update events as long as the UPDATE request is received.
- contains_object_list: send update events only if the UPDATE request carries any Object List

For each new LwM2M client that succeeds in going online, the gateway creates a subscription relationship to receive downstream commands and send it to the LwM2M client

fields.name: max_overflow
fields.desc: The maximum number of additional workers that can be created when all workers in the pool are busy. This helps to manage temporary spikes in workload by allowing more concurrent connections to the MongoDB server.

fields.name: overflow_ttl
fields.desc: Period of time before workers that exceed the configured pool size ("overflow") to be terminated.

fields.name: overflow_check_period
fields.desc: Period for checking if there are more workers than configured ("overflow").

fields.name: local_threshold_ms
fields.desc: The size of the latency window for selecting among multiple suitable MongoDB instances.

fields.name: connect_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The duration to attempt a connection before timing out.

fields.name: socket_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The duration to attempt to send or to receive on a socket before the attempt times out.

fields.name: server_selection_timeout_ms
fields.desc: Specifies how long to block for server selection before throwing an exception.

fields.name: wait_queue_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The maximum duration that a worker can wait for a connection to become available.

fields.name: heartbeat_frequency_ms
fields.desc: Controls when the driver checks the state of the MongoDB deployment. Specify the interval between checks, counted from the end of the previous check until the beginning of the next one. If the number of connections is increased (which will happen, for example, if you increase the pool size), you may need to increase this period as well to avoid creating too many log entries in the MongoDB log file.

fields.name: min_heartbeat_frequency_ms
fields.desc: Controls the minimum amount of time to wait between heartbeats.

fields.name: broadcast

fields.name: enable_qos3
fields.desc:
Allows connectionless clients to publish messages with a Qos of -1.
This feature is defined for very simple client implementations which do not support any other features except this one. There is no connection setup nor tear down, no registration nor subscription. The client just sends its 'PUBLISH' messages to a GW

fields.name: predefined

A 'pre-defined' topic ID is a topic ID whose mapping to a topic name is known in advance by both the client's application and the gateway

fields.name: password
fields.desc: The Connection String for connecting to Azure Event Hub.  Should be the "connection string-primary key" of a Namespace shared access policy.

fields.name: key
fields.desc: Template to render Azure Event Hub message key. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Azure Event Hub's NULL (but not empty string) is used.

fields.name: value
fields.desc: Template to render Azure Event Hub message value. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Azure Event Hub's NULL (but not empty string) is used.

desc: Template to render an Azure Event Hub message.

fields.name: topic
fields.desc: Event Hub name

fields.name: message
fields.desc: Template to render an Azure Event Hub message.

fields.name: max_batch_bytes
fields.desc: Maximum bytes to collect in an Azure Event Hub message batch. Most of the Kafka brokers default to a limit of 1 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 1 MB in order to compensate Kafka message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).

fields.name: partition_strategy
fields.desc: Partition strategy is to tell the producer how to dispatch messages to Azure Event Hub partitions. random: Randomly pick a partition for each message key_dispatch: Hash Azure Event Hub message key to a partition number

fields.name: required_acks
fields.desc: Required acknowledgements for Azure Event Hub partition leader to wait for its followers before it sends back the acknowledgement to EMQX Azure Event Hub producer all_isr: Require all in-sync replicas to acknowledge. leader_only: Require only the partition-leader's acknowledgement.

fields.name: kafka_headers
fields.desc:
Please provide a placeholder to be used as Azure Event Hub Headers
e.g. ${pub_props}
Notice that the value of the placeholder must either be an object: {"foo": "bar"} or an array of key-value pairs: [{"key": "foo", "value": "bar"}]

fields.name: kafka_ext_headers
fields.desc:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Azure Event Hub headers
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of kafka_headers field before sending to Azure Event Hub.

fields.name: kafka_header_value_encode_mode
fields.desc:
Azure Event Hub headers value encode mode
- NONE: only add binary values to Azure Event Hub headers;
- JSON: only add JSON values to Azure Event Hub headers, and encode it to JSON strings before sending.

fields.name: partition_count_refresh_interval
fields.desc: The time interval for Azure Event Hub producer to discover increased number of partitions. After the number of partitions is increased in Azure Event Hub, EMQX will start taking the discovered partitions into account when dispatching messages per partition_strategy.

fields.name: max_inflight
fields.desc: Maximum number of batches allowed for Azure Event Hub producer (per-partition) to send before receiving acknowledgement from Azure Event Hub. Greater value typically means better throughput. However, there can be a risk of message reordering when this value is greater than 1.

fields.name: buffer
fields.desc:
Configure producer message buffer.

Tell Azure Event Hub producer how to buffer messages when EMQX has more messages to send than Azure Event Hub can keep up, or when Azure Event Hub is down.

fields.name: query_mode
fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'async'.

fields.name: sync_query_timeout
fields.desc: This parameter defines the timeout limit for synchronous queries. It applies only when the bridge query mode is configured to 'sync'.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable (true) or disable (false) this bridge.

fields.name: bootstrap_hosts
fields.desc: A comma separated list of Azure Event Hub Kafka host[:port] namespace endpoints to bootstrap the client. Default port number is 9093.

fields.name: connect_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).

fields.name: min_metadata_refresh_interval
fields.desc: Minimum time interval the client has to wait before refreshing Azure Event Hub Kafka broker and topic metadata. Setting too small value may add extra load on Azure Event Hub.

fields.name: metadata_request_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum wait time when fetching metadata from Azure Event Hub.

fields.desc: Authentication configs.

fields.desc: Extra socket options.

fields.desc: SSL connection settings.

fields.name: local_topic

fields.desc: Azure Event Hub producer configs.

desc: Configuration for an Azure Event Hub bridge.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: cacerts
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.1.4.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.name: reuse_sessions
fields.desc:
Enable TLS session reuse.</br>
Has no effect when TLS version is configured (or negotiated) to 1.3

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.</br>
Has no effect when TLS version is configured (or negotiated) to 1.3

fields.name: log_level
fields.desc: Log level for SSL communication. Default is 'notice'. Set to 'debug' to inspect TLS handshake messages.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable TLS.

fields.name: server_name_indication
fields.desc:
Specify the host name to be used in TLS Server Name Indication extension.
For instance, when connecting to "server.example.net", the genuine server which accepts the connection and performs TLS handshake may differ from the host the TLS client initially connects to, e.g. when connecting to an IP address or when the host has multiple resolvable DNS records
If not specified, it will default to the host name string which is used to establish the connection, unless it is IP addressed used.
The host name is then also used in the host name verification of the peer certificate.
The special value 'disable' prevents the Server Name Indication extension from being sent and disables the hostname verification check.

fields.name: write_syntax
fields.desc:
Conf of GreptimeDB gRPC protocol to write data points. Write syntax is a text-based format that provides the measurement, tag set, field set, and timestamp of a data point, and placeholder supported, which is the same as InfluxDB line protocol.
See also [InfluxDB 2.3 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v2.3/reference/syntax/line-protocol/) and
[GreptimeDB 1.8 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.8/write_protocols/line_protocol_tutorial/) </br>
TLDR:</br>
```
<measurement>[,<tag_key>=<tag_value>[,<tag_key>=<tag_value>]] <field_key>=<field_value>[,<field_key>=<field_value>] [<timestamp>]
```
Please note that a placeholder for an integer value must be annotated with a suffix `i`. For example `${payload.int_value}i`.

fields.name: key_encoding_mode
fields.desc: Defines how the key from the Kafka message is encoded before being forwarded via MQTT. none Uses the key from the Kafka message unchanged. Note: in this case, the key must be a valid UTF-8 string. base64 Uses base-64 encoding on the received key.

fields.name: value_encoding_mode
fields.desc: Defines how the value from the Kafka message is encoded before being forwarded via MQTT. none Uses the value from the Kafka message unchanged. Note: in this case, the value must be a valid UTF-8 string. base64 Uses base-64 encoding on the received value.

fields.name: key
fields.desc: Template to render Kafka message key. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.

fields.name: value
fields.desc: Template to render Kafka message value. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.

fields.name: timestamp
fields.desc: Which timestamp to use. The timestamp is expected to be a millisecond precision Unix epoch which can be in string format, e.g. 1661326462115 or '1661326462115'. When the desired data field for this template is not found, or if the found data is not a valid integer, the current system timestamp will be used.

fields.desc: MQTT topic or topic filter as data source (bridge input).  If rule action is used as data source, this config should be left empty, otherwise messages will be duplicated in Kafka.

fields.name: kafka
fields.desc: Kafka producer configs.

fields.name: mode
fields.desc: Message buffer mode. memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages on disk are able to survive EMQX node restart. hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, Like memory mode, the messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart.

fields.name: per_partition_limit
fields.desc: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Kafka partition. When this limit is exceeded, old messages will be dropped in a trade for credits for new messages to be buffered.

fields.name: segment_bytes
fields.desc: Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid. This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.

fields.name: memory_overload_protection
fields.desc: Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.

desc:
Configure producer message buffer.

Tell Kafka producer how to buffer messages when EMQX has more messages to send than Kafka can keep up, or when Kafka is down.

fields.name: kafka_ext_header_key
fields.desc: Key of the Kafka header. Placeholders in format of ${var} are supported.

fields.name: kafka_ext_header_value
fields.desc: Value of the Kafka header. Placeholders in format of ${var} are supported.

desc:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Kafka headers
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of kafka_headers field before sending to Kafka.

fields.name: topic
fields.desc: Kafka topic name

fields.name: message
fields.desc: Template to render a Kafka message.

fields.name: max_batch_bytes
fields.desc: Maximum bytes to collect in a Kafka message batch. Most of the Kafka brokers default to a limit of 1 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 1 MB in order to compensate Kafka message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).

fields.name: compression
fields.desc: Compression method.

fields.name: partition_strategy
fields.desc: Partition strategy is to tell the producer how to dispatch messages to Kafka partitions. random: Randomly pick a partition for each message key_dispatch: Hash Kafka message key to a partition number

fields.name: required_acks
fields.desc: Required acknowledgements for Kafka partition leader to wait for its followers before it sends back the acknowledgement to EMQX Kafka producer all_isr: Require all in-sync replicas to acknowledge. leader_only: Require only the partition-leader's acknowledgement. none: No need for Kafka to acknowledge at all.

fields.name: kafka_headers
fields.desc:
Please provide a placeholder to be used as Kafka Headers
e.g. ${pub_props}
Notice that the value of the placeholder must either be an object: {"foo": "bar"} or an array of key-value pairs: [{"key": "foo", "value": "bar"}]

fields.name: kafka_ext_headers
fields.desc:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Kafka headers
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of kafka_headers field before sending to Kafka.

fields.name: kafka_header_value_encode_mode
fields.desc:
Kafka headers value encode mode
- NONE: only add binary values to Kafka headers;
- JSON: only add JSON values to Kafka headers, and encode it to JSON strings before sending.

fields.name: partition_count_refresh_interval
fields.desc: The time interval for Kafka producer to discover increased number of partitions. After the number of partitions is increased in Kafka, EMQX will start taking the discovered partitions into account when dispatching messages per partition_strategy.

fields.name: max_inflight
fields.desc: Maximum number of batches allowed for Kafka producer (per-partition) to send before receiving acknowledgement from Kafka. Greater value typically means better throughput. However, there can be a risk of message reordering when this value is greater than 1.

fields.name: buffer
fields.desc:
Configure producer message buffer.

Tell Kafka producer how to buffer messages when EMQX has more messages to send than Kafka can keep up, or when Kafka is down.

fields.name: query_mode
fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'async'.

fields.name: sync_query_timeout
fields.desc: This parameter defines the timeout limit for synchronous queries. It applies only when the bridge query mode is configured to 'sync'.

fields.name: health_check_interval
fields.desc: Health check interval.

fields.name: sndbuf
fields.desc: Fine tune the socket send buffer. The default value is tuned for high throughput.

fields.name: recbuf
fields.desc: Fine tune the socket receive buffer. The default value is tuned for high throughput.

fields.name: tcp_keepalive
fields.desc:
Enable TCP keepalive for Kafka bridge connections.
The value is three comma separated numbers in the format of 'Idle,Interval,Probes'
 - Idle: The number of seconds a connection needs to be idle before the server begins to send out keep-alive probes (Linux default 7200).
 - Interval: The number of seconds between TCP keep-alive probes (Linux default 75).
 - Probes: The maximum number of TCP keep-alive probes to send before giving up and killing the connection if no response is obtained from the other end (Linux default 9).
For example "240,30,5" means: TCP keepalive probes are sent after the connection is idle for 240 seconds, and the probes are sent every 30 seconds until a response is received, if it misses 5 consecutive responses, the connection should be closed.
Default: 'none'

fields.name: mode
fields.desc: Message buffer mode. memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages on disk are able to survive EMQX node restart. hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, Like memory mode, the messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart.

fields.name: per_partition_limit
fields.desc: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Pulsar partition. When this limit is exceeded, old messages will be dropped in a trade for credits for new messages to be buffered.

fields.name: segment_bytes
fields.desc: Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid. This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.

fields.name: memory_overload_protection
fields.desc: Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.

fields.desc: Maximum bytes to collect in a Pulsar message batch. Most of the Pulsar brokers default to a limit of 5 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 5 MB in order to compensate Pulsar message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).

This value will be respected only if 'remote.topic' is a shared subscription topic or topic-filter (for example `$share/name1/topic1` or `$share/name2/topic2/#`), otherwise only a single MQTT client will be used. Each MQTT client will be assigned 'clientid' of the form '${clientid_prefix}:${bridge_name}:ingress:${node}:${n}' where 'n' is the number of a client inside the pool. NOTE: Non-shared subscription will not work well when EMQX is clustered.

NOTE: if this bridge is used as the input of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then messages got from the remote broker will be sent to both the 'local.topic' and the rule.

fields.desc: Health check interval.

fields.desc: Whether start the resource right after created.

fields.name: start_timeout
fields.desc: Time interval to wait for an auto-started resource to become healthy before responding resource creation requests.

fields.name: auto_restart_interval
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.1.0.

fields.name: query_mode
fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'async'.

fields.name: request_ttl
fields.desc: Starting from the moment when the request enters the buffer, if the request remains in the buffer for the specified time or is sent but does not receive a response or acknowledgement in time, the request is considered expired.

fields.name: inflight_window
fields.desc: Query inflight window. When query_mode is set to async, this config has to be set to 1 if messages from the same MQTT client have to be strictly ordered.

fields.name: batch_size
fields.desc: Maximum batch count. If equal to 1, there's effectively no batching.

fields.name: batch_time
fields.desc: Maximum waiting interval when accumulating a batch at a low message rates for more efficient resource usage.

fields.name: enable_queue
fields.desc: Deprecated since v5.0.14.

fields.name: max_buffer_bytes
fields.desc: Maximum number of bytes to buffer for each buffer worker.

fields.name: type
fields.desc: Backend type.

fields.name: storage_type
fields.desc: Specifies whether the messages are stored in RAM or persisted on disc.

fields.name: max_retained_messages
fields.desc: Maximum number of retained messages. 0 means no limit.

fields.name: index_specs
fields.desc:
Retainer index specifications: list of arrays of positive ascending integers. Each array specifies an index. Numbers in an index specification are 1-based word positions in topics. Words from specified positions will be used for indexing.
For example, it is good to have [2, 4] index to optimize +/X/+/Y/... topic wildcard subscriptions.

desc: Configuration of the internal database storing retained messages.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable retainer feature

fields.name: msg_expiry_interval
fields.desc:
Message retention time. This config is only applicable for messages without the Message Expiry Interval message property.
0 means message will never expire.

fields.name: msg_clear_interval
fields.desc: Interval for EMQX to scan expired messages and delete them. Never scan if the value is 0.

fields.name: max_payload_size
fields.desc: Maximum retained message size.

fields.name: stop_publish_clear_msg
fields.desc:
When the retained flag of the `PUBLISH` message is set and Payload is empty,
whether to continue to publish the message.
See:
http://docs.oasis-open.org/mqtt/mqtt/v3.1.1/os/mqtt-v3.1.1-os.html#_Toc398718038

fields.name: delivery_rate
fields.desc: The maximum rate of delivering retained messages

fields.name: backend
fields.desc: Settings for the database storing the retained messages.

desc: Configuration related to handling `PUBLISH` packets with a `retain` flag set to 1.

fields.name: ipv6_probe
fields.desc: Whether to probe for IPv6 support.

fields.name: connect_timeout
fields.desc: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.

fields.name: pool_type
fields.desc: The type of the pool. Can be one of `random`, `hash`.

fields.name: pool_size
fields.desc: The pool size.

fields.name: enable_pipelining
fields.desc: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.

fields.name: ssl
fields.desc: SSL connection settings.

fields.name: headers
fields.desc: List of HTTP headers.

fields.name: max_retries
fields.desc: Max retry times if error on sending request.

fields.name: request_timeout
fields.desc: HTTP request timeout.

desc: Options for the HTTP transport layer used by the S3 client

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable this feature

fields.name: threshold
fields.desc: The latency threshold for statistics

fields.name: expire_interval
fields.desc: The eviction time of the record, which in the statistics record table

fields.name: top_k_num
fields.desc: The maximum number of records in the slow subscription statistics record table

fields.name: stats_type
fields.desc: The method to calculate the latency
